I went into The Perfect Tower II with a fair bit of excitement — the mix of incremental mechanics and tower-defense / automation elements really appealed to me. The game introduces a nice variety of playstyles: build-a-town, explore regions, choose between active and idle modes, experiment with different upgrades and towers. The developer notes that the game is still in Early Access and that “most of the game’s mechanics are done, but lack polish” which is refreshing honesty.

What works well

The core concept is solid: combining town building + automation + tower defence gives the game an interesting hybrid feel.

There is decent content already: 15 regions with different environments and modes (Normal, Endless, Challenge, Idle, Sandbox) to keep things varied. 
Steam Store

For players who enjoy tinkering and optimisation (setting up the “perfect tower”, automating things, exploring upgrades) there’s genuine potential.

What drags things down (for me)

My main sticking point: if you care about Steam achievements/hunting them, this game currently falls short in that department. The Steam page doesn’t emphasise a deep or fully developed achievement system (or at least I didn’t feel the achievement layer was present in the way I like).

Because I like setting long-term goals via achievements, the lack thereof significantly reduces the game’s staying power for me.

Being in Early Access means the game is still evolving, and this may change — but as it stands, the achievement-component simply isn’t enough to justify my continued investment, even though the gameplay hooks are there.

Verdict
If you’re someone who just wants a flexible, creative “build & automate” experience and don’t mind the absence of strong achievement support, The Perfect Tower II has a lot to like. However — if you, like me, live for Steam achievements, you’ll want to hold off or at least go in knowing that this aspect isn’t fully realised yet. In short: promising game, solid foundation, but for achievement-hunters it’s not quite there yet.
